tit.cmt: 僧兵（そうへい）→Sohei, priest soldier[Webster's Online Dictionary]

sen.j: 僧兵（そうへい）とは、日本の古代後期から中世、近世初頭にかけて存在した僧形の武者である。
sen.e: The term of Sohei means soldiers with the appearance of priests who were active from the Medieval Period until the early modern ages.
sen.cmt: 中世→the Medieval Period[英辞郎 on the WEB] 近世→modern ages [英辞郎 on the WEB] Sohei は複数扱いとしております（peopleと同様）
sen.e: The term Sohei means soldiers with the appearance of priests who were active from the Medieval Period until the early modern ages.
The term Sohei means samurai (warriors) with the appearance of priests who were active from the Medieval Period until the early modern ages.

sen.j: 概容
sen.e: General Information
General Information
Summary

sen.j: 法師武者あるいは武装した僧侶を僧衆、悪僧と同時代でいうが、それを江戸時代以降の「僧兵」と呼称したことばである。
sen.e: Hoshi-musha or armed priests were called Soshu or Akuso in the era when they were active but since Edo Period, they have been called "Sohei".
Hoshi-musha or armed priests were called Soshu or Akuso in the era when they were active but sincethe Edo Period, they have been called "Sohei".
Hoshi-musha or armed priests were called Soshu or Akuso in the era when they were active but since the Edo period, they have been called "Sohei."
sen.cmt: スペースを補足するなどしました。

sen.j: ちなみに悪僧の「悪」は悪党の悪と同じで「強い」という意味合いである。
sen.e: Incidentally, the Chinese character of "悪(aku)"used for the term of 悪僧(Akso), like 悪(aku) used for 悪党 (akuto) means "strong".
Incidentally, the Chinese character of "悪(aku)"used for the term of 悪僧(Akso), like 悪(aku) used for 悪党 (akuto) means "strong".
Incidentally, the Chinese character of "悪(aku)" used for the term of 悪僧 (Akuso), like 悪 (aku) used for 悪党 (akuto) means "strong."
sen.cmt: スペースを補足するなどしました。

sen.j: 主に寺院に所属する武装集団である。
sen.e: They basically belonged to temples as armed groups.
They basically belonged to temples as armed groups.
They basically belonged to temples as armed groups.

sen.j: その風貌は絵巻物などに描かれ、頭を包む布や、高下駄、薙刀などが特徴とされる。
sen.e: Their figures were depicted in picture scrolls and their characteristics are cloth covering heads, Takageta (tall wooden clogs) and Naginata (halberd).
sen.cmt: 高下駄→Takageta, tall wooden clogs[Webster's Online Dictionary]薙刀→Naginata, halberd[Webster's Online Dictionary]
sen.e: Their figures were depicted in picture scrolls and their characteristics are cloth covering heads, Takageta (tall wooden clogs) and Naginata (halberd).
Their figures were depicted in picture scrolls and their characteristics were cloth covering heads, Takageta (tall wooden clogs) and Naginata (halberd).

sen.j: 髪は剃っていなかった可能性が高い。
sen.e: It is highly possible that they didn't shave their heads.
It is highly possible that they didn't shave their heads.
It is highly possible that they didn't shave their heads.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィを半角にしました。

sen.j: なお、これに対し、神社に所属する武装集団を神人（じにん）という。
sen.e: In the meantime, armed groups belonging to shrines are called Jinin
In the meantime, armed groups belonging to shrines were called Jinin
In the meantime, armed groups belonging to shrines were called Jinin.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを追加しました。

sen.j: また、日本以外にも嵩山少林寺のように僧兵として武装集団を組織する仏教僧の集団がおり、広義には武装した宗教集団を指すこともある。
sen.e: As there were Buddhist monks' groups outside of Japan that organized monks into armed groups, such as Suzan Shorin-ji Temple (Mountain Sung Shaolin Temple), the term of Sohei sometimes refers to such armed religious groups in broad terms.
sen.cmt: 嵩山少林寺→Suzan Shorin-ji Temple, Mountain Sung Shaolin Temple[http://templeofreason.org/cyclopedia/Zen.htm]
sen.e: As there were Buddhist monks' groups outside of Japan that organized monks into armed groups, such as Suzan Shorin-ji Temple (Mountain Sung Shaolin Temple), the term Sohei sometimes refers to such armed religious groups in broad terms.

As there were Buddhist priests' groups outside of Japan that organized priests into armed groups, such as Suzan Shorin-ji Temple (Mountain Sung Shaolin Temple), the term Sohei sometimes refers to such armed religious groups in broad terms.

sen.j: その場合はヨーロッパの騎士修道会も含まれることがある。
sen.e: When used In this sense, Military Order in Europe is also included in the category of Sohei.
When used in this sense, the Military Order in Europe is also included in the category of Sohei.
When used in this sense, the Military Order in Europe is also included in the category of Sohei.

sen.j: 僧兵や神人が活躍した時代は社会が乱れる一方で、広大な寺領・神領を有して経済的に豊かであった寺社は盗賊のみならず、さまざまな勢力によって狙われる危険性が生じた。
sen.e: During the era when Sohei or Jinin were active, temples and shrines were rich with holding vast Jiryo (landownership of Buddhist Temple) or Shrine Estate amidst the unstable society and they faced with risks of being assailed by various social groups, including robbers groups.
sen.cmt: 寺領→Jiryo, landownership of Buddhist Temple [http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110001214654/]神領→Shrine Estate[http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110002366447/]寺社→temples and shrines[Webster's Online Dictionary]
sen.e: During the era when Sohei or Jinin were active, temples and shrines were rich due to holding vast Jiryo (landownership of Buddhist Temples) or Shrine Estates amidst the unstable society and they faced risks of being assailed by various social groups, including groups of robbers.

During the era when Sohei or Jinin were active, temples and shrines were rich due to holding vast Jiryo (landownership of Buddhist Temples) or Shrine Estates amidst the unstable society and they faced risks of being assailed by various social groups, including groups of robbers.

sen.j: このため、こうした動きから寺社を防衛する武力を保持する必要が出てきた。
sen.e: For this reason, a need to have military power for defending temples and shrines from such attacks arised.
For this reason, the need to have military power for defending temples and shrines from such attacks arose.
For this reason, the need to have military power for defending temples and shrines from such attacks arose.

sen.j: このような時代背景のもとに一見矛盾するように見える「寺院・神社の武装化」が推進される事になった。
sen.e: In this historic context, "arming of temples and shrines", though it seemingly sounds contradictory, was promoted.
In this historic context, "arming of temples and shrines", though it seemingly sounds contradictory, was actually promoted.
In this historic context, 'arming of temples and shrines,' although it seemingly sounds contradictory, was in fact promoted.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションにするなどしました。actually →in factに変更しました。though →althoughに変更しました。

sen.j: 京都・奈良市の大寺院の雑役に服する大衆（堂衆）が自衛武装したもの。
sen.e: Historicaly, Daishu (Doshu), those who belonged to big temples in Kyoto and Nara City and were engaged in odd jobs, armed themselves for self-defence and became Sohei．
Historically, Daishu (Doshu), those who belonged to big temples in Kyoto and Nara City and were engaged in odd jobs, and armed themselves for self-defence and became Sohei．
Historically, Daishu (Doshu), those who belonged to big temples in Kyoto and Nara City and were engaged in odd jobs, and armed themselves for self-defense and became Sohei.
sen.cmt: スペルなどを修正しました。

sen.j: 平安時代末期には強大な武力集団となり、興福寺・延暦寺・園城寺、東大寺などの寺院を拠点として、寺院同士の勢力争いや、朝廷や摂家に対して強訴をくりかえした。
sen.e: During the era of late Heian Period, Sohei became powerfull armed groups with their stronghold at Kofuku-ji Temple, Enryaku-ji Temple, Onjo-ji Temple and Todai-ji Temple etc. and repeatedly involved in power struggles among temples or acts of menace to the imperial court and Sekke (line of regents and advisers).
sen.cmt: 朝廷→imperial court[Webster's Online Dictionary]摂家→Sekke, line of regents and advisers[kotobank, Webster's Online Dictionary]
sen.e: During the era of the late Heian Period, Sohei became powerful armed groups with their stronghold at Kofuku-ji Temple, Enryaku-ji Temple, Onjo-ji Temple and Todai-ji Temple etc. and were repeatedly involved in power struggles among temples or in acts of menace to the imperial court and Sekke (line of regents and advisers).

During the late Heian period, Sohei became powerful armed groups with their stronghold including at Kofuku-ji Temple, Enryaku-ji Temple, Onjo-ji Temple and Todai-ji Temple and were repeatedly involved in power struggles among temples or in acts of menace to the imperial court and Sekke (line of regents and advisers).
sen.cmt: 表現などを変えました。

sen.j: 以仁王の乱では平家とも争う。
sen.e: In the rebellion led by Mochihito-o, Sohei also fighted against Heike clan.
In the rebellion led by Mochihito-o, Sohei also fought against the Heike clan.
In Mochihito-o War, Sohei also fought against the Taira family.

sen.j: 『平家物語』などにも、その描写がみられる。
sen.e: Such fight against Heike clan is depicted in Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike).
sen.cmt: 平家物語→Heike Monogatari, The Tale of the Heike[英辞郎 on the WEB]
sen.e: Such a fight against the Heike clan is depicted in Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike).
Such a fight against the Taira family is depicted in "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Taira family).

sen.j: 特に、興福寺（南都）は衆徒（奈良法師）、延暦寺（北嶺）は山法師と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Sohei belonging Kofukuji Temple (Nanto, southern capital) and Enryaku-ji Temple (Hokurei) were specifically called Shuto (Nara-hoshi) and Yama-hoshi respectively.
sen.cmt: 南都→Nanto, southern capital[http://www.eudict.com/?lang=engjpk&word=nara]衆徒→Shuto[kotobank]奈良法師→Nara-hoshi北嶺→Hokurei山法師→Yama-hoshi
sen.e: Sohei belonging to Kofukuji Temple (Nanto, southern capital) and Enryaku-ji Temple (Hokurei) were specifically called Shuto (Nara-hoshi) and Yama-hoshi respectively.
Sohei belonging to Kofuku-ji Temple (Nanto, southern capital) and Enryaku-ji Temple (Hokurei) were specifically called Shuto (Nara-hoshi) and Yama-hoshi respectively.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを補足しました。

sen.j: 白河天皇は、自分の意のままにならないものとして「賀茂川の水（鴨川の流れ）・双六の賽（の目）・山法師（比叡山）」を挙げているおり、僧兵の横暴が朝廷の不安要素であったことがうかがえる。
sen.e: Emperor Shirakawa cited "water of Kamo River (flow of Kamogawa River), cast of sugoroku and Yama-hoshi (Mt.Hiei-zan)"as what were beyond his control and from this anecdote, it can be guessed that the high-handedness of Sohei was worry for the imperial court.
sen.cmt: 白河天皇→Emperor Shirakawa[kotobank]賀茂川→Kamo River鴨川→Kamogawa River比叡山→Mt.Hiei-zan 双六→sugoroku[定訳不明]
sen.e: Emperor Shirakawa cited "water of the Kamo River (flow of Kamogawa River), cast of sugoroku and Yama-hoshi (Mt.Hiei-zan)"as being beyond his control and from this anecdote, it can be guessed that the high-handedness of the Sohei was a worry for the imperial court.

Emperor Shirakawa cited 'water of the Kamo River (flow of Kamo-gawa River), cast of sugoroku and Yama-hoshi (Mt. Hiei)' as being beyond his control and from this anecdote, it can be guessed that the high-handedness of the Sohei was a worry for the imperial court.

sen.j: 中央から離れた地域でも有力寺社は軍事力を持ったり地元軍事力と結びつき、当時のパワーバランスに大きな影響を及ぼしていた。
sen.e: Even in regions far from the center of Japan, some dominant temples and shrines exerted big influences on then power balance with holding military power or joining forces with the local militia.

Even in regions far from the center of Japan, some dominant temples and shrines exerted a big influence on the then power balance with holding military power or by joining forces with the local militia.

Even in regions far from the center of Japan, some dominant temples and shrines exerted a big influence on the power balance in those days with holding military power or by joining forces with the local militia.

sen.j: 治承・寿永の乱の時には熊野水軍を取り仕切っていた熊野権現にたいし双方から政治的な取引がなされた例などが著名である。
sen.e: It is well- known that during Jisho Jyuei no Nairan (Jisho Jyuei Rebellion), both sides made political deals with Kumano Gongen Deity that presided over Kumano Suigun.
sen.cmt: 治承・寿永の乱→Jisho Jyuei no Nairan, Jisho Jyuei Rebellion熊野水軍→Kumano Suigun[定訳不明]熊野権現→Kumano Gongen Diety[http://www.yamanashi-kankou.jp/spot/history_detail.html?id=c1877]
sen.e: It is well- known that during Jisho Jyuei no Nairan (Jisho Jyuei Rebellion), both sides made political deals with Kumano Gongen Deity that presided over Kumano Suigun.
It is well- known that during Jisho-Juei War, both sides made political deals with Kumano Gongen Deity that presided over Kumano Suigun Navy.
sen.cmt: 表現を変えました。Jyuei →Juei に変更しました。

sen.j: 室町時代に、かつて義円と名乗り天台座主だった足利義教が、僧兵の軍事力と粗暴さを熟知しているため、延暦寺討伐に動き出して大規模の弾圧を実施した（後年の信長も同様のことをやっている）。
sen.e: In Muromachi Period, Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, who had once been temple's head priest of Tendai sect and knew well about military power and high-hadedness of Sohei, conducted massive military operations in order to crack down Enryaku-ji Temple (Nobunaga conducted similar operations later).
sen.cmt: 義円→Gien[kotobank]天台→Tendai sect座主→temple's head priest[http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definition/temple%2527s+head+priest]足利義教→Yoshinori ASHIKAGA[Yahoo辞書]信長→Nobunaga
sen.e: In the Muromachi Period, Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, who had once been a temple head priest of the Tendai sect and knew well about the military power and high-handedness of Sohei, conducted massive military operations in order to crack down on Enryaku-ji Temple (Nobunaga conducted similar operations later).

In the Muromachi period, Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, who was formerly known by Gien and had once been a temple head priest of the Tendai sect, was familiar with the military power and high-handedness of Sohei to conduct massive military operations in order to crack down on Enryaku-ji Temple (Nobunaga conducted similar operations later).
sen.cmt: 「かつて義円を名乗り」を補足し表現を変えました。

sen.j: 各地の有力寺社が軍事力を保持する傾向はその後も続いた。
sen.e: Even after that, dominant temples and shrines in various regions continued to hold military power.
Even after that, dominant temples and shrines in various regions continued to hold military power.
After that, such trend of those dominant temples and shrines in various regions to hold military power continued.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)の有力僧兵団として以下の例がある。
sen.e: Followings are the examples of powerful Sohei group during the age of civil war(Japan).
sen.cmt: 戦国時代→the age of civil war[Webster's Online Dictionary]
sen.e: The following are examples of powerful Sohei groups during the age of civil war(Japan).
The following are examples of powerful Sohei groups during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).
sen.cmt: スペースを補足し、用語を統一しました。

sen.j: 興福寺・・・宝蔵院流槍術の開祖・胤栄などが知られる。
sen.e: Kofuku-ji Temple ・・・ Inei, the founder of The Hozoin-Ryu Sojutsu School of spearmanship is known widely.
sen.cmt: 宝蔵院流槍術→The Hozoin-Ryu Sojutsu School of spearmanship[http://www4.kcn.ne.jp/~hozoin/E-index.html]胤栄→Inei[kotobank]
sen.e: Kofuku-ji Temple ・・・ Inei, the founder of The Hozoin-Ryu Sojutsu School of spearmanship is known widely.
Kofuku-ji Temple; Inei, the founder of the Hozoin school of Sojutsu (the art of the spearman ship), was well-known.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とし過去形にするなどしました。

sen.j: 根来寺・・・津田流砲術の開祖・津田算長をはじめ、強力な火縄銃隊で知られる。
sen.e: Negoro-ji Temple ・・・ It is well-known for its mighty harquebus corps and Kazunaga TSUDA, the founder of Tsuda-ryu gunnery.
sen.cmt: 根来寺→Negoro-ji Temple[http://www.negoroji.org/]津田流→Tsuda-ryu砲術→gunnery, artillery[Webster's Online Dictionary]津田算長→Kazunaga TSUDA[kotobank]
sen.e: Negoro-ji Temple ・・・ It is well-known for its mighty harquebus corps and Kazunaga TSUDA, the founder of Tsuda-ryu gunnery.
Negoro-ji Temple; it was well-known for its mighty harquebus corps including Kazunaga TSUDA, the founder of Tsuda school of gunnery.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とし過去形にするなどしました。

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉による紀州征伐で制圧され、軍事力を喪失した。
sen.e: It was subdued by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI by his expedition to Kishu and lost military power.
It was subdued by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI by his expedition to Kishu and lost military power.
It was subdued by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI by his expedition to Kishu and lost military power.

sen.j: 石山本願寺・・・独自の僧兵集団ではなく、各地の門徒（多くは国人や庶民）を動員した一向一揆を通じて絶大な影響力・軍事力を誇ったが、石山合戦に敗れ壊滅、軍事力を喪失した。
sen.e: Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple ・・・ It boasted overwhelming influencial power as well as military power through Ikko Ikki which was fought by, instead of its own Sohei group, believers called up from every region of the country (many of them were indegenous persons and ordinary people), but eventually it suffered devastating defeat in Ishiyama War and lost its military power.
sen.cmt: 石山本願寺→Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple[http://kids.gakken.co.jp/jiten/1/10009190.html]門徒→Monto, believer, follower[Webster's Online Dictionary]国人→Kokujin, indigenous person, inhabitant of a country[kotobank, Webster's Online Dictionary]一向一揆→Ikko Ikki石山合戦→Ishiyama War[http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110000499116/]
sen.e: Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple ・・・ It boasted overwhelming influencial power as well as military power through Ikko Ikki which was fought by, instead of its own Sohei group, believers called up from every region of the country (many of them were indegenous persons and ordinary people), but eventually it suffered devastating defeat in the Ishiyama War and lost its military power.

Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple; it boasted overwhelming influential power as well as military power through Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikko sect followers) which was fought by, instead of its own Sohei group, believers called up from every region of the country (many of them were indigenous persons and ordinary people), but eventually it suffered devastating defeat in the Ishiyama War and lost its military power.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とするなどしました。

sen.j: 諏訪大社・・・武田信玄に制圧され、軍事力を喪失した。
sen.e: Suwa-taisha Shrine ・・・ It was subdued by Shingen TAKEDA and lost military power.
sen.cmt: 諏訪大社→Suwa-taisha Shrine[http://park14.wakwak.com/~systemheart/suwataisya/]武田信玄→Shingen TAKEDA
sen.e: Suwa-taisha Shrine ・・・ It was subdued by Shingen TAKEDA and lost military power.
Suwa-taisha Shrine; it was subdued by Shingen TAKEDA and lost military power.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とするなどしました。

sen.j: 大名家としては江戸時代に再興したが、神官家とは分かれることになった。
sen.e: It was rebuilt as the line of feudal lord but was split from that of Shinto priest.
It was rebuilt as the line of the feudal lord but was split from that of the Shinto priest.
It was rebuilt as the line of the feudal lord but was split from that of the Shinto priest.

sen.j: 宇佐神宮・・・大友義鎮に制圧され、軍事力を喪失した。
sen.e: Usa-jingu Shrine ・・・ it was subdued by Yoshishige OTOMO and lost military power.
sen.cmt: 宇佐神宮→Usa-jingu Shrine[http://www.usajinguu.com/Frame.html]大友義鎮→Yoshishige OTOMO[kotobank]
sen.e: Usa-jingu Shrine ・・・ it was subdued by Yoshishige OTOMO and lost military power.
Usa-jingu Shrine; it was subdued by Yoshishige OTOMO and lost military power.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とするなどしました。

sen.j: いずれも江戸時代までには軍事力を喪失するか、分割されるなどして宗教と軍事力が切り離されている。
sen.e: Before the start of Edo Period, all temples and shrines mentioned above had either lost their military power or been split and religion and military power had been seperated.
Before the start of the Edo Period, all temples and shrines mentioned above had either lost their military power or had been split and religious and military power had been seperated.
Since all temples and shrines mentioned above had either lost their military power or had been divided, their religious powers had been separated from the military powers by the Edo period.

sen.j: 日光山輪王寺・・・多数の僧兵を抱え、下野国でも有数の武装勢力になる。
sen.e: Nikko-zan Rinno-ji Temple ・・・ It held many Sohei and was one of the leading armed group in Shimotsuke Province.
sen.cmt: 日光山輪王寺→Nikko-zan Rinno-ji Temple[http://www.rinnoji.or.jp/]下野国→Shimotsuke Province
sen.e: Nikko-zan Rinno-ji Temple ・・・ It held many Sohei and was one of the leading armed groups in Shimotsuke Province.
Rinno-ji Temple on Mt. Nikko; it held many Sohei and was one of the leading armed groups in Shimotsuke Province.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とするなどしました。

sen.j: 後北条氏に荷担したため、豊臣秀吉により弾圧され、寺領を没収され衰退。
sen.e: Because it joined forces with Go-Hojo clan, it was oppressed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, forfeited its Jiryo and declined.
Because it joined forces with Go-Hojo clan, it was oppressed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, forfeited its Jiryo and declined.
Because it joined forces with the Gohojo clan, it was oppressed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI to be forfeited its Jiryo, then declined.

sen.j: 関東に移封された徳川家康の保護により、勢力を回復する。
sen.e: Later, it recovered its clout under the protection of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who had been transferred to Kanto.
Later, it recovered its clout under the protection of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who had been transferred to Kanto.
Later, it recovered its clout under the protection of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who had been transferred to Kanto.

sen.j: 談山神社・・・興福寺と度々武力衝突を起こす。
sen.e: Tanzan-jinja Shrine ・・・ It often clashed with Kofuku-ji Temple.
Tanzan-jinja Shrine ・・・ It often clashed with Kofuku-ji Temple.
Tanzan-jinja Shrine; it often clashed with Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とするなどしました。

sen.j: 天正13年（1585年）、大和国に入国した豊臣秀長の武装解除要求に応じ、武具を供出。
sen.e: In 1585, it accepted the disarmament request made by Hidenaga TOYOTOMI when he came to Yamato Province and surrendered weapons.
sen.cmt: 天正13年（1585年）→in 1585大和国→Yamato Province豊臣秀長→Hidenaga TOYOTOMI[kotobank]
sen.e: In 1585, it accepted the disarmament request made by Hidenaga TOYOTOMI when he came to Yamato Province and surrendered weapons.
In 1585, it accepted the disarmament request made by Hidenaga TOYOTOMI when he came to Yamato Province and surrendered weapons.

sen.j: 平泉寺白山神社・・・延暦寺末寺として、最盛期には8千人の僧兵を抱えて越前国に勢力を伸ばす。
sen.e: Heisen-ji Temple Hakusan-jinja Shrine ・・・As the branch temple of Enryaku-ji Temple, it held eight thousands Sohei and extended its power to Echizen-no-kuni.
sen.cmt: 平泉寺白山神社→Heisen-ji Temple Hakusan-jinja Shrine[http://kanko.gnavi.co.jp/spot/31/18000731.html]末寺→branch temple[Webster's Online Dictionary]越前国→Echizen-no-kuni (越前国)[定訳不明]
sen.e: Heisen-ji Temple Hakusan-jinja Shrine ・・・As the branch temple of Enryaku-ji Temple, it held eight thousand Sohei and extended its power to Echizen-no-kuni.
Heisen-ji Temple Hakusan-jinja Shrine; as the branch temple of Enryaku-ji Temple, it held eight thousand Sohei and extended its power to Echizen Province.
sen.cmt: 「・・・」を「;」とするなどしました。

sen.j: 天正2年（1574年）、一向一揆との抗争で全山が焼失。
sen.e: In 1574, it was burnt down in the battle against Ikko Ikki and declined thereafter.
In 1574, it was burnt down in the battle against Ikko Ikki and declined thereafter.
In 1574, it was burnt down in the battle against Ikko Ikki.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 勢力が弱まる。
sen.e: It was declined thereafter.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 織田信長、豊臣秀吉と早くから結び、寺領を回復する。
sen.e: However, by allying itself with Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI from early on, it recovered its Jiryo.
However, by allying itself with Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI from early on, it recovered its Jiryo.
However, by allying itself with Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI from early on, it recovered its Jiryo.
